body: Will be in Nairobi this weekend on a business trip, but still have a some afternoons and one full day free (Thursday). Have seen some good tips on markets, tipping, etc., but some of them are dated several months back. Please advise:1. Reasonable tipping (hotel bellboy, taxi driver, waiters at cafes or restaurants, etc.)2. A good supermarket close to downtown where I can shop for Kenyan-made specialties, especially dry foods.3. An open-air Maasai market for Thursdays.4. A good place to buy ebony artifacts (best if it has good fixed prices, no haggling!)5.Nairobi National Park: is it a walk-in, or do I need to book with a travel service?6. Best place to change money (banks? exchange offices?)7. A good cafe near downtown Nairobi where I can enjoy genuine taste of Kenyan coffee.8. A good restaurant near downtown Nairobi serving Kenyan food.Thanks
title: Updates on Nairobi Please

answers.body: Nairobi National Parkis not a "walk in", but the Animal Orphanage, by the Park Gate, is.
answers.title: 1.Re: Updates on Nairobi Please

answers.body: Tut1) Ksh50–100 for hotel staff, but better to leave Ksh1000 per room per day in the general staff tip box that's normally found in the lobby. Don't tip taxi drivers who usually work for themselves and will charge what they can. Tip the waiting staff 10% at a restaurant and people will be pleased. Small change or Ksh50–100 will go down well in bars or cafés.2) Any Nakumatt s'market will have plenty of everything, including local dry foods.3) The Maasai markets aren't currently operating on Thursdays.4) Please don't buy endangered ebony. It's the ivory of the plant kingdom.5) Nairobi Nat Park requires a vehicle. Take a taxi for a few hours, or get your hotel to organise a minibus with a pop-up roof.6) Get your cash with a debit card from any ATM.7) Branches of Java are usually good. But only as good as the freshest pot. Ask them to make fresh if it's stewed. It's always Kenyan.8) Tell us where your hotel is and someone will recommend a nearby restaurant. You don't want to be driving across the city to eat.Have a good time!Richard
answers.title: 2.Re: Updates on Nairobi Please

answers.body: If staying at a "full-service" hotel, you'll find gift shops with much the same items as in the markets. Often the prices maybe higher, but so too is the quality. Though prices can be comparable to that in a market. The hotels all serve Kenyan coffee and I find that it's as good here as in a coffee shop.You can arrange thru your hotel to visit theNational Park, or use a taxi, but arrange price beforehand.There's also the Giraffe Center (open all day) and Sheldrick Elephant Orphanage (11am daily, 1/hr only) are all nearby the Natl Park.There are a few Nakumatt markets around NBO, so best to find the one nearest your hotel... again, you'll probably need a taxi.Use ATMs for local KSH.The tipping advise Richards provided is spot on!
answers.title: 3.Re: Updates on Nairobi Please

answers.body: Dear all.Thanks a lot for some very useful tips. I will start using them in a couple of days.RichardThanks for telling me about the ebony issue. Last time I was there (some 14 years ago) ebony was 100% legal, while ivory and ostrich eggs were not (that's only what I knew about, but I believe there were also some animal skins and probably other stuff as well.) However, like many other places in the world, there were always "in-person" offers to sell illegal merchandise!Kind regards.King-Tut
answers.title: 4.Re: Updates on Nairobi Please

answers.body: King-TutI've probably given the wrong impression. I don't whether there are any *legal* issues around ebony carvings, just that it's a highly endangered wood andKenyahas used up most of its stocks and imports the wood fromTanzania. This website has some coverage (I'm sure other TA users will be aware of better sources)http://www1.american.edu/ted/ebony.htmAs for ivory and other wild animal products, trade in all of them in Kenya is effectively illegal. That's obvious in the case of ivory and rhino horn, but the ban also includes sea shells, sea urchin carapaces and other marine animal products – not that you'd know it from the open way they're sold on the beaches.Ostrich shells, from farmed birds, are probably okay these days!Anyway, have a great trip.Richard

answers.body: Richard.Thanks for the tip on ebony--I will not try to buy any, even if it's sold legally.Re: Ostrich egg shells:Although not a natural habitat for ostriches,Egypthad banned egg shells for several years. But in the past few years, fresh eggs from locally -farmed birds were legally sold in supermarkets. However, I believe that importing of shells, especially carved ones, is still illegal.KT

answers.body: Dear allOnce again thank you very much for the valuable tips. I'm now on my last day in Nairobi, and enjoyed my stay very much. People are warm, weather is charmingly cool but traffic still runs on the wrong side of the road!Yaya shopping center (somewhere) and Nakumatt (downtown) were very good.Almost all sellers of wooden artifacts first claim they're made of ebony, and they give you solid evidence. When I told them I wouldn't buy ebony (taking a TA expert's advice!!) and they are about to lose the deal, they then say that (the very same) artifacts are made of tanned rosewood, and again, they give you solid evidence! LOL! Price of course goes down by at least 20% at this point, then you continue to haggle for at least 10-20% more.Had a lot of work to do outside working hours, so unfortunately didn't have time to visit the Park or any of the museums--have to leave something for the next time.I enjoyedKenyafor this second time (first time was on my honeymoon, over a decade ago) and wish I will be able to visit again.Thank you once again.

answers.title: 1.Re: Place near Nairobi?

answers.body: In answer to your questions1. Attractions are spread out across Nairobi. For example, places like theGiraffe Centre,Karen Blixen Museum, Elephant Orphanage, Animal Orphanage andNational Parkare all very close to Karen, on the outskirts. If you were to stay somewhere like, say,Macushla House, you would be located in Langata and therefore within 15-20 minutes' driving time of all of the above, traffic permitting. Then, for the downtown attractions such as theNational Museumand others listed in the previous post, you could organise with your hotel / B&B to hire a taxi plus driver for the day to take you into town and wait while you visit them. Alternatively, you could stay in a downtown hotel and do your sightseeing vice versa. Personally speaking, I'd go for the outskirts option as it's cheaper and quieter and Nairobi, IMHO, is a pretty grotty city!2. For accommodation on the outskirts I would recommend:Macushla HouseNgong HouseGiraffe ManorPalacina Suites/ResidenceHTHFL410

body: Hello fellow travellers!First off, I wanna thank everyone that already uses this forum, because it has greatly helped us plan other parts of our Africa trip in the past and for the coming year already.We do still have a question regarding accommodation.The following is our itinerary (yes, it's a bit jam packed for some, but this is partially a business trip doing some research for client travel):July 7 - Fly to Nairobi, Overnight ???July 8 - Drive to Serengeti, ON Speke BayJuly 9 - Full day Serengeti, ON Speke BayJuly 10 - Full day Serengeti, ON Speke BayJuly 11 - Drive back around through Western Masai Mara into Eastern area, 3/4 day in park, ON Sopa LodgeJuly 12 - Full day Masai Mara, ON Sopa LodgeJuly 13 - Morning in Masai Mara, return to Nairobi, flight in evening to JobergWe arrive in Nairobi fromCape Townaround 2:30pm (7th) and are trying to determine what our best option is before driving around into the Serengeti (driving to Speke Bay, which is on the far west edge of the park).Option 1 - Overnight in Nairobi and leave first thing the next morning for the long drive into the Serengeti.We are down to the following 4 locations to stay: Country Lodge, Fairview,Nairobi Safari Club, andNdemi Place. We would do a bit of touring around before settling into our hotel, but are also concerned about safety as the day moves on.Option 2 - Start driving towards Serengeti, but stay somewhere along the way that evening (maybe drive 2-4 hours?). Our concern was finding somewhere safe and reasonable for a quick overnight. Don't need anything luxury by any means, but we also don't want to stay in anything budget (again, safety concerns).Any recommedations if there are any places to stay along the way? We planned to take the B3-A1-B6 hwy route around to the lodge.If not, are there any recommendations which location would be best for the overnight inKenya? We might do something like the elephant orphanage or giraffe centre upon arrival.The main purpose of our trip is the self drive in Serengeti and Masai Mara. We were going to stay the entire time in the Masai Mara and drive into the Serengeti, but we found out you cannot drive between parks from within the parks, so we have to go all the way around in order to do both. Unfortunately, the rest of our trip is set and we don't have much extra time to give to these parks than listed above.The reason we have chosen to drive is because we, have done, and enjoy self driving the parks (might pick up a guide for a day or two when we enter, as this is pretty cheap).Other options like flying into Kilimajaro came out pretty expensive and this is the best we've come up with so far.Any suggestions or recommendations would be greatly appreciated. We have doneSouth Africabefore, but never Kenya andTanzania.Thanks again everyone,Mark

answers.body: Well, if only wanting to catch the migration in the Serengeti, flying into Mwanza, renting a vehicle and self-driving would work. Just be sure you know where you're going (there's little signage), where petrol stations are located and have some understanding of the local language.However, if you wish to be in the Serengeti, which area? Western or Northern? Herds are often in the West, but can also be in the North. Regardless which, makes no sense to be overnighting at Speke Bay which entails departing the Serengeti and returning daily (long and tedious besides there's NO off-roading while in the Serengeti).Best you arrange lodging or tented camp in the area of Serengeti you'd be visiting.

title: Masai Market - Worth a later flight?

answers.body: Unfortunately neither. It's basically a group of (mostly) Maasai traders in the car park at Village market (Nairobi's most high-end mall). And that's it. . .They sell Maasai beadwork and most of the usual wooden and soapstone carvings and other souvenirs that you can find all over. Not to say that the Maasai markets aren't fun to browse, but not if you've been in a beautiful place like Lamu, where you can buy most of the same stuff (not Maasai beadwork on the whole, to be fair) from interesting little shops in the town's alleys. I would be spending a final morning in Lamu!Elephant orphans might swing it I guess (11am-noon - actually you probably would barely make it on time). Final thought: you could probably make a last-minute decision the day before.Richard

answers.body: With a week, don't limit yourself to Nairobi! I'd definitely suggest you get out of Nairobi.We trust things will have cooled down by November and all will be back to normal.Do you have priorities - places, people, wildlife, beach???If you have enough money and not time, consider flying. answers.body: Naivasha & Nakuru are within travelling distance if they are now safe - others will tell for sure. But In Nairobi thee is still I believe enough to fill a week's spare time. Bird walk wednesday mornings from outside theNational Museum@ 8.30am. Also in this vicinity you have the national Museaum and the reptile place just about 200yards away. In the and near the city centre you have The Nationa Archives (put an afternoon aside for this - well at least a couple of hours)and theRailway Museumand this is before we start adding things likeNairobi National Park, Animal Orphanage,Safari Walk, Giraffe Sanctuary, Karen Blick House this list goes on and on.
answers.title: 3.Re: 1 week to explore area

answers.body: I may be a bit biased, but I feel just remaining in Nairobi doesn't give the best picture ofKenyaas a whole. It is a land of amazing contrasts - from the Coast to the cooler heights. From lush farmland to desert. From well dressed, seemingly rich, people to the desperately poor and needy.You can cross the Equator at over 9000ft and feel cold up there!! You can swim in pools fed by hot springs.........I am a "people person" - most Kenyans are warm hearted and friendly. In your charity work, you are very likely to see needs which may make you a bit uncomfortable doing some touristy things!! If I were you, I'd not make too many plans in advance, unless you want to book a safari. (In that case you can get much advice on this forum.)TIA (This Is Africa) and last minute decisions are the norm, unless it it booking a popular hotel or safari!

answers.body: Hi Mike,I have just returning fromKenyaon a volunteer program based inKibera. Yes i would recommend a trip through Kibera. The only reason i suggest this is because you mentioned your work inUganda. Kibera is not for the average 'tourist'.Things are quite bad there and the mere size of the place is unbelievable. 1.5 million people living in a 'real' slum. It is the largest in all of africa. There is a spot at a school called 'olympic' where you can get a great view of Kibera.Despite the conditions the people, especially the kids, are great.If you can find someone a local that is trustworthy get them to take you through. If you can get them to drive you to an area Jamhuri and then it is a 10min walk to Kibera. If you stay on the outer rim and don't take valuable you will get a better feel than a drive through. I arrive Friday night at 9 pm in Nairobi with KLM.I do not have any budget restrictions as such.Best regardsChristian Wieth
title: Weekend in Nairobi

answers.body: If no budget restrictions, you can consider- first thing Sat morning, transfer to Wilson (domestic) airport for 10am flight to Masai Mara, have game drive, overnight; Sunday morning game drive and afternoon game drive to airstrip for 4pm flight to Wilson.-Instead of the Masai Mara, you could fly 7:30am to Amboseli or (9-something) to Samburu, both known for large elephant herds; Amboseli also has views of Kili; Samburu has species not found elsewhere as: reticulated giraffe, Grevy's zebra, gerenuk, Somali ostrich, Beisa oryx and even wild dogs.However, with these two destinations, there are only morning flights so once back in NBO on Sun, you'd have half-day free, but there is some interesting sightseeing:Karen Blixen Museum, Giraffe Center, by 11am Sheldrick Elephant Orphanage; if you adopt an ellee (see the Sheldrick site) you can arrange to visit your chubby at 5pm to meet the keeper and put your ward to sleep... lots of fun .---You'd incur fee for return flights, 1/nt lodge or camp (many choices at different budgets), meals, park fees, game drives and transfers - your hotel can arrange, but I'd prebook before arrival.Easier and probably less expensive probably- Sat morning, road trip to Lake Nakuru; game drive, hotel overnight Lion Hill Lodge; next morning (Sun) early game drive and drive south (1/hr) to Naivasha for boat ride to Crescent Island for walking safari amongst tame game; return to NBO by evening. (about 2-2.5/hrs drive time)OR- Sat morning, road trip to Ol Pejeta, private conservation - stay at Sweetwater's, Porini Camp or Ol Pejeta Bush Camp (if open in Nov); game drives, night game drives; Sunday, game or walking safaris; return to NBO by evening. (about 2-2.5/hrs drive time).--- Cost for either of these should include: guide/vehicle, park fees, room/tent, meals, game drives and all transfersHope this helps.

body: It looks like we have about a 6 hour layover before coming back home in the Nairobi airport around 5pm. Was thinking about possible going into Nairobi for dinner from the airport. Is this advisable, and if so how is best to do it safely? Thank you.
title: Layover

answers.body: I do this quite often. Land at 4pm from Kigali and then fly out on the 11pm to London. BUT a few provisos: I always check my bags through and I always have my boarding card for the second leg of my flight (online check in is fab), so all I have to do on my return to the airport is go through immigration. I also tend to fly on a Sunday night, when the roads are quiet(er), so I can be in and out of town quickly.You will need to buy a transit visa for $10. If you're not at the front of the queue I wouldn't bother as you'll waste too much time and you might just as well sit at Java Coffee by gate 14.I tend to go to Karen rather than town (nicer restaurants) -Talisman,Rusty Nailetc - just jump in a cab at the airport, and get the restaurant to book one for your return. It'll cost you c1200Ksh into town (30 mins) and c1500Ksh to Karen (40mins). I tend to head back so I'm at the airport 90 mins before the flight.This has gone spectacularly wrong on one occassion when the traffic was so bad it took 4 hours to get back from Karen.If you wanted something closer you could go to dinner at the Parnasi (sp?) Hotel which is about 10 minutess from the airport.If in any doubt on time don't do it.
answers.title: 1.Re: Layover

answers.body: Just be warned about the Nairobi traffic - 5pm could be dreadful!!Our visitors last week took 2 1/2 hours to get into Nairobi at noon and missed their planned trip to the Game Park.Personally I'd not bother!! The Cafe up past Gate 14 looks nice....

answers.body: the gate 14 cafe / coffee shop (the cafe's much cheaper than the coffee shop by the way - even though they share the same space) is ok but it's always packed as its one of the few places to sit - the bar called 'The Pub' on the road between Domestic and International terminals looks OK (my transfers have always been too short to sample it)Is your layover between two international flights or after an internal one? (ref transit visa)

title: One night in Nairobi

I'd check with Zim Embassy if this inoc is needed which is rather expensive. Also, taxi to/from hotel.And, for a 7:20am flight you have to be at airport for check-in/security at minimum 2/hrs prior departure (it's an international flight). Thus, gather you'd have to be up, showered, dressed, had breakfast and out of hotel by 5am.While NBO airport isn't attractive enough nor at all comfortable, services limited... you might do better finding a quiet spot here to catch some Zzzzs. Some shops will be open and though few places to eat, Java (Coffee) House is best you might be able to "hang" here till early morning.Good luck!

body: Hello~We'll be brought back to the airport after a safari with about 10 hours til our flight home.Any suggestions as to what to do in the area during that time? I'd really rather not sit around at the airport all day :)Thanks! Jen
title: 10 hours before flight home...what to do?

answers.body: I had a similar long hour wait after arriving atWilson Airporttil flight took off around 10 pm at JKIA. This is a familiar scenario for many coming from Safari. I had a driver take me to David Sheldrick Elephant Orphanage at 11am then had previously booked a day room at the Fairview hotel to rest and freshen. It is a lovely business hotel on southwest side of city but situated so as 1/2 hour drive (allow 2 hours before check-in) to airport. I had lunch at outdoor restaurant and a nap. There are some street wares just outside of hotel grounds if you want any last minute gifts. Nairobi can be dangerous (traffic bad) so don't go out with any valuables or not at all. I learned that everything is negotiable so don't fall for any of the street scams or high price quotes. There are probably day room prices ($80US) that can be negotiated depending on business so check around. The Sarova Pan-Afrik is right behind the Fairview and has a nice pool area. Rooms are basic but clean.
answers.title: 1.Re: 10 hours before flight home...what to do?

answers.body: Your biggest problem is Nairobi traffic. A lot depends on your time of arrival and departure.

I can make a few suggestions, visit the elephant orphanage, the giraffe centre which opens fbetween 9am to 5pm, this will leave you with ample time to get to the airport. mind you the traffic jam could be horendous.you can also visit the bomas of kenya or the carnivore restuarant, the museum or snake park.

The Eka was nice and close to the airport, since our flight arrived late, we only slept there, but also ate there before our return flight home. Security seems tight, and location was good to the airport. We did the day thing in Nairobi before our late night return flight home, on our last day. Was plenty of time to visit the Giraffe Center and elephant orphanage to fill up the time gap between our flight into Wilson (after safari), and our scheduled return flight home out of NBO at midnight. I enjoyed the Masai Mara National Park, but being early June, the grass was tall and wildlife not so easy to spot. My favorite camp we visited was the Ol Kinyei Conservancy, Mara (very exclusive) and plenty of wildlife to see (grass not so tall). If you're not into the 'crowds' it was the highlight of our trip.

body: As a frequent visitor to Nairobi leading tour groups, I have now decided to avoid the Hotel Boulevard completely. It badly needs refurbishment, the management has no idea how to run a professional hotel, and they treat their Kenyan staff very shabbily. The crowning touch was on January 27/2006 when my group was among 40 people who despite having confirmed bookings were bumped by a Kenya Airways flight cancellation. My clients were sent to very sub-standard hotels. The Boulevard hotel has great potential, but the current owners (also owners of the Hotel 680) seem bent on running it into the ground. I recommend travellers avoid the Boulevard at all costs!

body: I am arriving at 1.20 am and would like to know the best and safest hotel near to the airport, to which i can get a shuttle bus at that hour in the morning.
title: hotels near the jomo kenyatta airport

answers.body: Hello,We suppose you are asking for shuttle bus as a mean of commuting from the Airport to the Hotel, well, to my opinion i would you get your self some more organized pick up arrangement done before hand. This way you are sure you are going to be picked up as soon as the flight lands.The choice of hotel then may not necessarily be confined to the proximity of the Airport as you will be dropped to your hotel safely.Having said that there are several options of nearby Airport hotels among them is Panari hotel, Ole Senari relatively new, Hill park hotel, Mvuli Park and many more depending on your budget. At that time it hardly takes twenty min to the city center as its clear all the way hardly any traffic. Its usually twenty Usd one way to the city center in a private transfer cab. Will pm you some choices.Have a hassle free transfer.John

answers.body: I HAVEN'T STAYED BUT i believe theNorfolkhas a good reputation and many friends have found it excellent.
answers.title: 2.Re: hotels near the jomo kenyatta airport

answers.body: At that hour there won't be any traffic, so whether you stay near the airport or in city center shouldn't matter. Panari and Ol Sereni aren't inexpensive, so depending on budget and where you're heading next morning, maybe staying in the city itself would provide more options.Many like Fairview or Country Lodge with fairly good prices.
answers.title: 3.Re: hotels near the jomo kenyatta airport

answers.body: You don't say whether you are transiting or staying longer? There isn't an airport shuttle bus - some of the better hotels might offer their own transport which you would have to arrange beforehand. The best thing is to order a private cab to wait for you - the driver will meet you at the barriers just outside the customs check at arrivals.As the OPs have mentioned, traffic at that time of the night is negligible, however if you need to return to the airport the next day to catch a flight allow at least 2 hours to get there, especially in the late afternoon or on Fridays. Even if the normal traffic is okay, quite often something happens (like a police shoot out with gangsters, or the presidential calvalcade, or a political speech at the stadium - all of which have happened to me) which stops traffic for hours on end (which means the cab might have trouble even getting to pick you up, let alone deliver you to the airport).If you are staying for a while, choose a hotel near the city or at Westlands - Westlands is safer I reckon, and there are cafes and restaurants there and at the Sarit Centre so you aren't stuck at the hotel, plus shops and the Maasai markets (in tin sheds on the corner opposite Sarit Centre) to buy some gifts. (The touts at the markets can be quite pushy though, so maybe team up with someone else if possible.)Jacaranda Hotelis fine and doesn't charge like a wounded bull.Also check TripAdvisor for guesthouses etc - the Mennonite Guesthouse off Rhapta Road is about 40 mins walk from Westlands shops, for example, but don't walk at night or evening.Andrews Apartments(also a hotel - at the end of Rhapta Road near St Marys schools) is really nice with a quiet green outlook (ask for a room looking over St Marys parkland) and pool, but not sure of their pricing.Also, maybe make a deal with your cab driver to drive you around for your stay - public transport as we know it doesn't exist, and can be dangerous. I can recommend Francis from Westline Travel (+254 (0) 724 988 866), or Nellion cabs (+254 (0) 734 354 738), or JimCabs. One way trip from JKIA into town/Westlands will be 1500 shillings - this is the standard. Further out (say to Karen) would be more.
answers.title: 4.Re: hotels near the jomo kenyatta airport

answers.body: At that hour and time you cant get a bus. The best is to book a transfer with a local operator to pick you from the airport and drop to any hotel in the city centerHotels nearest to JKIA are Panari Hotel and the new (I would recommend) is Ole Sereni Hotel. These two hotels are approx 10 min drive excluding any traffic.Others are located in the city center. Nairobi Serena, Intercontinental Hotel, Panafric Hotel, The Stanley just to mention a few. All these hotels are safe and it all depends on your budget

title: Places of interest in route Nairobi to Masai Mara

answers.body: The Great Rift Valley view point is one of the most interesting places to have a short stop, Masai Market at Narok town. Its quite scenic on your way to Narok town.Be prepared for quite a bumpy ride, a couple of hours before you get to the Main gate at Masai Mara (Sekenani gate) the road is in quite a bad condition.

answers.body: Those flights are so easy to do. We see kids on them all the time. Have taken all of our nieces and nephews since they were two, and nobody has been sick or felt uncomfortable.If you drive in, your driver will guide you in the Mara. It is such a better experience to have a local guide from the Mara. These guys know the Mara like the back of their hand, have their own networks, etc., and I can 100% guarantee you that your safari experience will be ten folds better with the local guides.Most of the driver guides from Nairobi rely on their radio for calls on what people have seen, and then all rush in for the sighting and then rush on for the next. The local guides avoid the masses, and take you for a truly special safari experience.

body: Hello,I am visitingKenyafor only 3 days early April 2017, before heading toSeychelles.It is my first trip to Africa and my wife and I really want a good Africa experience.We are going to do a 4 day safari at the Kruger NP, but I don't think it is going to be enough, that is why we've decided to visit Kenya.What you guys recommend for the 3 days? Does it worth visiting Maasai Mara or Amboseli? Is Nairobi a good place to visit for only one day.I am a bit lost, so any help will be great.Cheers.
title: 3 days in Kenya

answers.body: Do you have three full days or are parts of the first/third days taken up by international travel? If that's the case then I think you'd be looking at flying by private charter to Mara, Amboseli or Tsavo as soon as you enterKenya, and passing two nights in the park. Nairobi isn't worth seeing on such a tight itinerary, or even a longer one in my honest opinion.Edited: 26 December 2016, 18:17
answers.title: 1.Re: 3 days in Kenya

answers.body: If you wish to visit either the Mara or Amboseli you'll have to fly to/from.Note that the flights for Amboseli depart NBO (Wilson domestic) airport early morning around 8am and another at about 2pm.. For the Mara, flights depart Wilson around 10am and at about 3pm..Checkin for any is minimum 45min prior departure..If your arrival and departure into/out of NBO doesn't work with these, enjoy your visit at Kruger.
answers.title: 2.Re: 3 days in Kenya

answers.body: if i was in your place... i will choose mara than amboseli....if budget is not an issue fly to mara spend 2 nights ..if budget is low better go to ol pageta..... its same distance to amboseli... but better game

body: Greetings!I will be staying in Nairobi for about 2 months starting in late June. I will also be returning to Nairobi next year for at least 12 months. I am hoping to find an inexpensive room or apartment fairly near the National Museums ofKenyafor this summer and, potentially, for when I move back. I prefer to find a place in a non-ex-pat community or perhaps a homestay. Does anyone know of a good way of finding a place to rent or to share with a family/roommate/student? Are there good ways to get connected or to find postings for apartments from abroad or once I am in Nairobi?Thanks!
title: inexpensive longer-term housing

answers.body: There is probably more scope for finding accommodation for the 12 month stay, when you are there for two months. The National Museums are located in the Parklands/Westlands area and the nearest mall, Sarit Centre has a noticeboard where accommodation adverts are posted. The local newspapers also carry ads for accommodation. For longer term property rentals, it is not uncommon for 3 - 6 months deposit to be asked for. Also repainting the accommodation at the end of the tenancy is often a clause in the agreement, which you arrange and fund.I found these, during a quick search:https://www.airbnb.co.uk/rooms/2424954?s=5gsO…capitalfm.co.ke/property/residential-proper…expat-blog.com/en/…flats-for-rent.htmlhttp://www.homestay.com/kenya/nairobiYou have not mentioned your budget, but accommodation in Westlands, particularly can be quite expensive. Cheaper accommodation can be found in other areas of the city, but there is the distance and travel to consider, plus your own personal safety.Edited: 11 June 2014, 10:18
answers.title: 1.Re: inexpensive longer-term housing

answers.body: Areas around the National Museums ofKenyaare quiet expensive and may require early booking since is largely ex-pat areas,if i knew your budget i could be more specific on which district would suit you best.I also know someone who would gladly organize a home stay within westlands which is nearThe National Museumand the area i live accommodation is also available -for two months(but you will be required to pay one month rent and one month deposit which is refundable)It is also secure with lots of volunteer and students from Europe residing here.Edited: 11 June 2014, 18:01

body: I'm sure there's someone out there who can advise me!I'm staying at theFairview Hotelfor 2 nights in Nairobi before joining a project and would like to do the tourist bit - elephant orphanage etc. for one day. As a single middle aged female would it be better (and safer) to join a organised trip (and if so can anyone make any tour company recommendations) or would booking a taxi or guide be a suitable option.Also suggestions on what to see would be great (apart from the eles)Many thanks

answers.body: Hi skipuss,Using a taxi would be a cheaper option for you but you might need a guide. This is a safe way to travel around Nairobi. Finding an organized group might not be easy because of conflict of dates and timings.Apart from the elephant orphanage you can do the giraffe manor> nice place to interact within the giraffes one on one. The safari walk and animalorphanage also are nice places to visit. All this can be done in one day but the elephant orphanage only opens for one hour. Btw 11 and 12 to minimize their tolerance to human beings.All the best.
answers.title: 2.Re: Best way to be a single tourist for 1 day in Nairobi

answers.body: Or you could adopt a baby ele and then you can arrange to go for longer in the day.
answers.title: 3.Re: Best way to be a single tourist for 1 day in Nairobi

answers.body: A day in Nairobi can be such fun!! Of course, the elephants are a must. Are you a foster parent of one of the orphans? If you are, did you know you can have a more private viewing in the evening when you can meet your baby personally!!! This was definitely a highlight for me. Email the trust to arrange. Other highlights are theGiraffe Centrewhere you can feed the giraffes and learn more about them,Karen Blixen Museum(Out of Africa), Bomas of Africa, a cultural village where you will learn about the tribes and watch them perform,Utamaduni Craft Centrefor more up-market crafts. Carnivore Restaurant is also a lot of fun but probably better if you have company. All of these attractions are in Langata an outer suburb of Nairobi, so all close by to each other.I have friends in the safari business in Nairobi who I would recommend to you, but not sure how their cost would compare to other forms of travel for a single person. Please try them.East Africa Discoveries and Safaris, run by Isaac Kariuki, email safari@eastafricad.co.ke OR eastafricad@yahoo.com.www.eastafricad.co.keAsk for David to guide you ... he is also a friend and a wonderful guide, very professional and polite. I am also a middle aged female and always felt safe in his company. I loveKenyawith a passion and will definitely be going back. I'd love to know more about your project ... please reply??!!!

body: Dear forum,I would like to ask you for advice regarding the visa policy inKenyaand theJomo Kenyatta Intl Airport.I am an EU citizen. I will be traveling (+1 person) from Zanzibar to Nairobi International Airport (with Fly 540, arrival 7.3.2015 at 14:10) from where I will continue toVienna(Turkish airlines, departure from Nairobi is on 8.3.2015 at 4:45 AM)..That means we will have to wait at the airport in Nairobi for more than 14 hours.1. Will I have to pay 50 USD for visa, or can I avoid it by not leaving the international transit lounges?2. Is it advisable to spend that much time at the airport in transit? Are there facilities that would make the waiting worthwhile, or at least tolerable?What would you suggest? Stay in transit / Rent a room for the night / Or find different flights?thanks a lot
title: Spending a night at Jomo Kenyatta Intl Airport

answers.body: 14hrs thats alot of time. I would advice to get a room for the night or check on other airlines too. All the best.
answers.title: 1.Re: Spending a night at Jomo Kenyatta Intl Airport

answers.body: If you remain 'airside', then you won't need to buy a visa. However, Jomo Kenyatta International is not a very inspiring place in which to spend 14 hours - there are a few duty free shops and a couple of decent coffee shops. Its difficult to spend that amount of time there, unless you have a tablet or similar loaded with movies!If you want to look for alternative flights; Emirates andQatarhave flights which depart late afternoon/early evening and in my opinion,Dubaiis a more tolerable place to wait (don't know about the new airport at Doha).If you wanted to get out of the airport, a Transit Visa is valid for 72 hours and costs 10 GBP (or $ equivalent).
answers.title: 2.Re: Spending a night at Jomo Kenyatta Intl Airport

answers.body: Having just come through JKIA I cannot imagine anyone spending 14 hours there without going crazy. There is the Simba Lounge that you could upgrade to but that is all.My first choice would be to find different flights. Start with routes from ZNZ avoiding NBO sector altogether. Go via DAR so no new Visa required IF a long stay still needed.Or bite the bullet, get a transit Visa and a cheap lodge nearby. Or just see the town and head back to the airport around midnight after a decent meal somewhere.BUT be aware the NBO traffic is horrendous even at that hour. Our plane was late as the turnround crew could not get through the abysmal security q in time.
answers.title: 3.Re: Spending a night at Jomo Kenyatta Intl Airport

answers.body: You will have to decide what you are going to do before getting off the plane, because since the fire at the airport in 2013 all international flights are met on the tarmac by buses. There are two sets of buses, one for transit passengers who are taken to the transit area of the Departures Terminals, and the other for people whose destination isKenya, who are taken to the Arrivals Hall.If you choose to leave the airport for a hotel and your bags are checked through to your final destination you will not have access to them, and as said above you will need a transit visa which cost 15€.There was only one lounge left at the airport after the fire and this was reserved for Kenya Airways (KQ) and it's Skyteam partners business and first class passengers. Recently a new terminal (1A)was opened which is dedicated to KQ and it's partners, while passengers of other airlines continue to use the old departure terminal.The new one contains several cafes, bars, restaurants and it will have two new lounges (again restricted to KQ and Skyteam first and business class passengers). The last I heard (November 2014) they had opened one of the new lounges and the other was almost ready to open, but had still retained use of the Simba Lounge in the old departures area, which seems a bit selfish, unless they were going to release it for other airlines once both new ones were open. (Maybe if Mfuwe used the old Simba lounge they have?)You can access the new terminal and its restaurants etc from the old departures area, there is an entrance next to Java House (Coffee / Restaurant / Bar) next to gate 14, although it is airside you still have to go through the scanners again. So you are not limited to Java House and a couple of small cafes like you used to be before the new terminal opened.

answers.title: 8.Re: Currency, things to do in five days

answers.body: Food, services (except for hotels/safari) and shopping are priced in Kenya Shillings. Although US Dollars are likely to be accepted, you are unlikely to be offered a favourable exchange rate. It is better to bring some cash which you can exchange, or withdraw Kenya Shillings from ATM's (ensuring that you notify your bank of travel plans). Card payments are accepted in many retail outlets, but more remotely located outlets eg. curio shops will operate on a cash basis.Also, I would urge you to pay tips in Kenya Shillings. Kenyan's are too polite to turn down a tip made in US Dollars. However, the reality is that the member of staff might not be readily able to change the money and will also lose on the exchange, as well as possibly needing to pay for travel to a bank/forex. I also believe that it demonstrates respect and forethought to pay tips in the legal tender.

body: I traveled toKenyain August with my wife and two kids (10,12) for a six night safari with AfricaPoint. Overall it was a superb trip, with only one flaw (with the itinerary). The price was very reasonable when compared to what others charge for the same itinerary. Everything was included in the price except for drinks (we did get the company to provide bottled water in the vehicle throughout the trip) and tips. We couldn’t possibly have been happier with our driver/guide Paul. Not only was he a great guide, he also was a careful driver, particularly in the one stretch where the drivers are dangerous. An executive from the company had lunch with us on the last day (while in Nairobi), and he asked for us to provide the pros and cons of the trip. That’s a good sign that they are serious about customer satisfaction. I planned the trip after checking out the lodges on Tripadvisor, and AfricaPoint accomodated me on all my requirements.If you get the chance, head to the Nairobi area in August, which is comfortable weather (mostly in the 70s) and is the peak time for the wildebeest migration in the Masai Mara. The Kenyan winter (if you can call it that) was wonderful after coming from the heat of the Egyptian summer.We arrived at 0300 in Nairobi after an overnighter from Cairo. Someone from AfricaPoint was there to greet us, although he wasn’t carrying a sign, so it took a few minutes to link up. That’s one of the few glitches in the trip. The driver took us to the Panafric Hotel in Nairobi, where we had a good, relaxing breakfast. Paul, our driver/guide, arrived to pick us up around 0800. I was glad to see that the driver on our trip wasn’t the same as the one who picked us up at 0300; having a sleepy driver wouldn’t be a good start. Paul drove us to our first destination at the Serena Mountain Lodge at Mt. Kenya, after a stop at a souvenir store. He recommended that we buy stuff their, saying it was the best bargain around. However, since it was our first day, and we had nothing to compare it to, and hadn’t built up a trust in Paul yet, we only bought a few small items. If you have Mt Kenya as your last stop before Nairobi, that’s the largest store we visited. We arrived at the lodge at lunchtime.The Serena Mountain Lodge was the perfect place to spend our first night in Kenya. After the overnight flight and a 3-4 hour drive, staying at a place where you can see the animals from your lodge was very relaxing. It’s quite a thrill to enter the lodge from the side facing away from the watering hole, and then to see it from the lobby. There were about eight elephants roaming around, plus other animals (details in the hotel section, where we also reviewed the other lodges mentioned below). We also went on a nature walk that included a stop for tea. The rooms, all of which face the watering hole, were comfortable and the meals were great. You can check off a list of animals that you would want to be awakened for, including hyenas and civit cats. Since it’s an older lodge, if you have noisy neighbors, you will need some earplugs. We didn’t have any problems, though.The next day we drove to Lake Nakuru, also approximately a four hour drive, with part of it bone jarring. It’s surprising that the main roads north of the city, where the tourists go, are in such bad shape. The bad part didn’t last too long, though, and after entering the park, we were treated to lots of zebras, monkeys, baboons, buffalos, and could see the millions of pink flamingos on the salt water lake. We stayed in a two-bedroom bungalow at the Sarova Lion Hill, which was a beautiful place with lots of colorful birds and attractive grounds. For the evening game drive, it’s only took about five minutes to get back into the wildlife, which included about a dozen white rhinos, giraffes, lions, wart hogs, and other animals, and white flamingos, great white pelicans, and lots of other birds on the lake. In the evening we enjoyed an African dance troop. The only knock on this lodge was the uncomfortable mattresses, which were everywhere except at the Serena Mountain Lodge. Overall, it was a wonderful second part of the trip.Day three involved another stop at the lake before heading off to the Masai Mara, where we arrived by lunch. As with the trip to Lake Nakuru, there is a rough stretch to this road too. It’s interesting, though, to see the villages en route, including the Masai tribal villages. We spent two nights in two upstairs rooms in a four room bungalow at the Mara Simba Lodge. This is a very open lodge which overlooks a lazy river where hippos, crocodiles, ibises, baboons, monkeys and a large monitor lizard could be seen. We had an afternoon game drive on the first day, and two game drives on our second day there. We saw thousands of wildebeest, lots of lions, and almost every animal that they have in the park, including a leopard up close, and a cheetah. The only disappointment we had was missing out both mornings on a hot air balloon ride due to high winds (a rarity there). We absolutely loved the Masai Mara, since we saw so many animals. Two nights worked out just fine, but you could stay three nights and still benefit. Make sure you try to see a river crossing site for the wildebeests.Day five was the only major mistake on the trip. I had provided the itinerary, planning on driving from the Masai Mara to Amboseli. The company-provided itinerary details showed that we would arrive at Amboseli by lunch. We ended up arriving late in the evening, after a 3-4 hour drive to the capital, where we had a good lunch at the Panafric Hotel again, followed by a drive on the dangerous stretch (lots of fast moving vehicles weaving in and out, and lots of road work) leading from the capital to the south. After about two hours of that bad stretch, we turned off for the road to Amboseli, which had been recently paved and had few other cars on it. That part fine, but the last half hour was on a very dusty stretch that hadn’t been paved yet. We arrived in time for dinner, and were pretty tired. Paul commented that whoever had filled out our itinerary details had clearly never made that trip. The executive that joined us for lunch that day already knew about the glitch and assured us that future customers would be advised to spend the night in Nairobi.We stayed two nights at the Amboseli Sopa Lodge. It’s a beautiful site with nice large, two room bungalows, well manicured gardens, and a little hill where we saw hornbills and mongeese. At nighttime you can return to the hill and see a feeding. They placed meat on a large rock, and then out came a striped hyena (rare, unlike the spotted hyenas you can see in the park), a black badger, a couple of large white-tailed mongeese, and several house cats! The whole menagerie clearly meets each night, and the cats are ignored by the hyena and other critters. When the weather cooperates, you can see Mt. Kilimanjaro from the lodge. On our last morning there, out popped the mountain for about 1.5 hours, before entirely disappearing from sight. The meals at this lodge were fine, but not as good as at the other places. The park is not as interesting as the Masai Mara. We saw many of the same animals, with the major benefit being the elephants up close (we saw them up close at the Serena Mountain Lodge, but not up close at Masai Mara), quite a few hyenas, several types of eagles, and other birds that we hadn’t seen before.Our trip back to Nairobi was uneventful. We had a very late night flight, so we opted for a visit to the animal orphanage, which was a disappointment. We thought we would see baby animals, but the orphanage is where animals are brought as young, but kept for the rest of their lives. Since you will see most of these animals in the wild, this is no more exciting than visiting a zoo. Although we didn’t do it, I would imagine that the Village Market is the place to go to get your last-minute souvenirs. We ended up having dinner at the Carnivore Restaurant, which we highly recommend.Bottom line from this trip. We had the best vacation of our lives (and that’s saying something, since I’ve been many places). The itinerary was almost perfect, the weather was great, AfricaPoint was reasonably priced, and Paul was truly outstanding as a driver and guide. We highly recommend AfricaPoint. If you have some extra money, consider asking for a Range Rover, which is probably more comfortable on the sections of rough road than the standard minibus. It’s not a big deal, though; we were certainly satisfied with the minibus.

In the evening we enjoyed an African dance troop. The only knock on this lodge was the uncomfortable mattresses, which were everywhere except at the Serena Mountain Lodge. Overall, it was a wonderful second part of the trip.Day three involved another stop at the lake before heading off to the Masai Mara, where we arrived by lunch. As with the trip to Lake Nakuru, there is a rough stretch to this road too. It’s interesting, though, to see the villages en route, including the Masai tribal villages. We spent two nights in two upstairs rooms in a four room bungalow at the Mara Simba Lodge. This is a very open lodge which overlooks a lazy river where hippos, crocodiles, ibises, baboons, monkeys and a large monitor lizard could be seen. We had an afternoon game drive on the first day, and two game drives on our second day there. We saw thousands of wildebeest, lots of lions, and almost every animal that they have in the park, including a leopard up close, and a cheetah. The only disappointment we had was missing out both mornings on a hot air balloon ride due to high winds (a rarity there). We absolutely loved the Masai Mara, since we saw so many animals. Two nights worked out just fine, but you could stay three nights and still benefit. Make sure you try to see a river crossing site for the wildebeests.Day five was the only major mistake on the trip. I had provided the itinerary, planning on driving from the Masai Mara to Amboseli. The company-provided itinerary details showed that we would arrive at Amboseli by lunch. We ended up arriving late in the evening, after a 3-4 hour drive to the capital, where we had a good lunch at the Panafric Hotel again, followed by a drive on the dangerous stretch (lots of fast moving vehicles weaving in and out, and lots of road work) leading from the capital to the south. After about two hours of that bad stretch, we turned off for the road to Amboseli, which had been recently paved and had few other cars on it. That part fine, but the last half hour was on a very dusty stretch that hadn’t been paved yet. We arrived in time for dinner, and were pretty tired. Paul commented that whoever had filled out our itinerary details had clearly never made that trip. The executive that joined us for lunch that day already knew about the glitch and assured us that future customers would be advised to spend the night in Nairobi.We stayed two nights at the Amboseli Sopa Lodge. It’s a beautiful site with nice large, two room bungalows, well manicured gardens, and a little hill where we saw hornbills and mongeese. At nighttime you can return to the hill and see a feeding. They placed meat on a large rock, and then out came a striped hyena (rare, unlike the spotted hyenas you can see in the park), a black badger, a couple of large white-tailed mongeese, and several house cats! The whole menagerie clearly meets each night, and the cats are ignored by the hyena and other critters. When the weather cooperates, you can see Mt. Kilimanjaro from the lodge. On our last morning there, out popped the mountain for about 1.5 hours, before entirely disappearing from sight. The meals at this lodge were fine, but not as good as at the other places. The park is not as interesting as the Masai Mara. We saw many of the same animals, with the major benefit being the elephants up close (we saw them up close at the Serena Mountain Lodge, but not up close at Masai Mara), quite a few hyenas, several types of eagles, and other birds that we hadn’t seen before.Our trip back to Nairobi was uneventful. We had a very late night flight, so we opted for a visit to the animal orphanage, which was a disappointment. We thought we would see baby animals, but the orphanage is where animals are brought as young, but kept for the rest of their lives. Since you will see most of these animals in the wild, this is no more exciting than visiting a zoo. Although we didn’t do it, I would imagine that the Village Market is the place to go to get your last-minute souvenirs. We ended up having dinner at the Carnivore Restaurant, which we highly recommend.Bottom line from this trip. We had the best vacation of our lives (and that’s saying something, since I’ve been many places). The itinerary was almost perfect, the weather was great, AfricaPoint was reasonably priced, and Paul was truly outstanding as a driver and guide. We highly recommend AfricaPoint. If you have some extra money, consider asking for a Range Rover, which is probably more comfortable on the sections of rough road than the standard minibus. It’s not a big deal, though; we were certainly satisfied with the minibus.

answers.body: Downtown Nairobi is interesting, but not worth the traffic. It looks a lot like other capital cities in developing countries. If you wanted to go theNational Archivesit might be worth it, but you'll burn the whole day getting into town from Karen, wandering around a bit, and getting back.Taxis around Karen shouldn't be too bad and would never approach the $100 USD they are charging. Hell, if you want a name, I will give you a driver's name and number who is trustworthy and they will ferry you all day for much less than $100. If you find taxis around, be prepared to barter some.You can also use Uber, which is now popular in Nairobi. I don't use it, but the prices seem to be a bit cheaper than taxis.

body: Hello all!Any ideas are very welcome...We will be arriving back in Nairobi from a 5 day safari and thought it would be nice to spend a night in Nairobi before heading for the overnight train to Mombasa - just to break up the journey a bit.We had provisionally booked a room atGiraffe Manor, fancying somewhere rather extravagant to stay for the night, but were very surprised when they informed us by email that we would have to find something to do in the day before the train as we would have to vacate the manor (i.e. not just the room!) by 10am!We wont be arriving back into Nairobi from the Masai Mara until mid to late afternoon for our overnight stay, so it is too much of a bitter pill to swallow to pay such a lot of money for just the one night in the circumstances. I had assumed that they would at least be able to accommodate storing bags and perhaps a cup of tea when we came back to collect the bags before the train, given that it was going to cost in the region of £550 for the night for two people.So... I am now debating between either biting the bullet and getting the overnight train a night earlier, or still staying overnight in Nairobi to break up the journey, but somewhere else.Any recommendations? We had fancied Giraffe Manor as a bit of an indulgence, opportunity to get "up close and personal" with the giraffes there, and be able to have a nice afternoon tea, but have been rather put off by their responses over email... We were going to use the arrival day to relax/enjoy nice surroundings after a few days camping, and then use the following day to visit the elephant orphanage/Giraffe centre before the train, so had also been rather sold on the lack of time in a taxi!Thanks ahead of time for any tips/advice!
title: Alternative to Giraffe Manor?

answers.body: Check-out most hotels is 10am (as checkin is 11am... need time to clean rooms and prepare for incoming guests), so if you intend to stay longer for a late flight or, as in your case, the overnight train... people add on a "dayroom" which even at the GM is very expensive and check-out for this is by 6pm.Other luxe properties could be House of Waine, Palacina Suites,Ngong House, but they too have 10am checkout.You might just do as you mention... on return from Mara do some shoppiing, have an early dinner somewhere and just head to train station for trip out to the coast. Or, take a dayroom (any hotel within budget) to refresh and then transfer to train station for trip out to the coast.
answers.title: 1.Re: Alternative to Giraffe Manor?

answers.body: Thanks for the advice Sandi - I'll have a look at those hotels as well.Perhaps this is the "norm" for Nairobi then... I was just very surprised what I go the email. I've only blown the budget to this degree on a couple of occasions (Lake Palace inUdaipur/Dorchester in London and the like) when it seems "justified" and on these occasions have got myself comfortable with spending so much money by knowing that I would be able to enjoy the surroundings the next day to some degree along with doing the requisite sightseeing. In my (very limited) experience when you spend that kind of money on a nights' accommodation places usually bend over backwards on the customer services stakes.I hadn't really considered trying to get a day room as I'd only really expected them to store baggage somewhere and perhaps allow us to sit in communal areas to relax with a cup of tea for half an hour when picking up the luggage in between sightseeing and heading to the train.I'll have a think about what is best... I guess the choices are either biting the bullet, still staying atGiraffe Manorand dealing with the issue of left luggage/karting it around Nairobi at the time or (like you say) just finding somewhere to chill out a bit before the train and head straight out to the coast the same day.
answers.title: 2.Re: Alternative to Giraffe Manor?

answers.body: Unlike a hotel with public lobby and choice of bar and restaurant/s where guests or non-guests can bend elbows or grab a meal... or simply "lookie-sees" who plop down on a chair...Giraffe Manoris small (6/rooms) and private. For paying guests only using their lovely, but small lounge area or enjoying the grounds. Their prices reflect the exclusivity.
answers.title: 3.Re: Alternative to Giraffe Manor?

answers.body: 4sandi is absolutely right. Staying atGiraffe Manoris like having (part of) your own small country house - which is one reason why it costs so much. We were also told that they couldn't look after our bags after check-out - and, having stayed there (and having loved every minute of it), I totally understand and agree with their policy (in the event, we took our bags with us in the car for the day: no problem at all). It simply isn't a hotel in any kind of conventional sense, so it's really not a question of 'bending over backwards in the customer services stakes'. Personally, I thought it was a wonderful - and wonderfully unique - place which was worth every penny, but it definitely isn't a Dorchester/Lake Palace kind of establishment if that's what you are expecting. If you do decide to stay there, I'm sure you'll see why it really wouldn't work to have ex-guests coming and going during the day.
answers.title: 4.Re: Alternative to Giraffe Manor?

answers.body: Hello all - sorry, I think I sounded more critical of GM than I meant to in my previous post!I hadn't expected to spend much time at all at GM the following day, and had only hoped that they would simply look after baggage and perhaps allow us a quick cup of tea when we came back to collect luggage before our train.I hadn't expected to be able to spend lots of time there the following day as I do understand the size is small, and am not naive enough to think GM is like Lake Palace/Dorchester - the only reason for drawing a comparison in my own mind is that these are the only few times I've really pushed the boat out and spent a lot of money on just one nights' accommodation as an extravagant treat.I think I was only hoping to get our money's worth a bit - we were going to be paying full-board price but only spending a short amount of time there on the day we were booked in because of a long transfer during the day, and were therefore missing some of the meals included in the rate we were paying so I had hoped there might have been a bit of flexibility the next day given the cost (I had been quoted, I think, £580 for the night).On this occasion, the time we would be able to spend at GM probably doesn't justify the cost (and this is just for us - I know everyone is different) - if we were able to check in at the usual 11am and be able to enjoy the surroundings for the day then it seems like a wonderful treat to splash out on, but since we are arriving later in the day then it is best to stay somewhere more affordable in Nairobi and save our "treat" at another point in the vacation.Thanks all again.
answers.title: 5.Re: Alternative to Giraffe Manor?

answers.body: Thanks for getting back to us - I do understand where you were coming from! We were lucky enough to be able to check-in at 11am, so did have the full benefit of a night at GM. As I recall, they do offer a half-board rate for people who can't get there in time for lunch - but I don't think that it cuts the cost by very much - as well as an expensive day-room rate, as 4sandi said. Although we did have to vacate our room by 10am next morning, we certainly weren't rushed off the premises - in practice, we were welcome to have another coffee on the terrace and actually left around 10:45 (as the first of next day's guests were arriving). Incidentally, we used GM to book a car for us (at a reasonable price) to use on our departure day: by the time we had been to the elephant orphanage, the Karen Blixen museum, had some lunch, done some shopping, been back to the orphanage to say goodnight to our adopted ele and driven into town it was about 7pm - could that work with the Mombasa train?Edited: 12 January 2011, 04:48
answers.title: 6.Re: Alternative to Giraffe Manor?

answers.body: One of the very last things myself & my wife did when we went to Nairobi was to visit theDavid Sheldrick Wildlife Trust(http://www.sheldrickwildlifetrust.org/) It is purely a rescue/rehabilitation centre for baby elephants. Thusly they only are open for ONE HOUR a day between 11am & 12:00pm (Noon) while the baby elephants have a feed and a mudbath. I recommend you plan on arriving at least 20 minutes before then as there can be quite a queue and you would be disappointed if you missed out on the experience by arriving too late.I strongly recommend anyone whom has an opportunity to visit to take it, as not only will you get to experience these big babies up close, but you will help with your entry fee/donation as well as the profits from any of the merchandise you buy (we ended up walking out with about 6000ksh of shirts & paraphernalia and it was worth every shilling as we knew the money was going to a good cause. This was a once in a lifetime experience for us, i seriously recommend you consider doing the same.

body: I needed a place to stay with my family for 4 weeks as we moved to Nairobi. We booked Oasis B&B on-line, as it was one of the very few places in the vicinity of where we wanted to be. I found it very expensive for what it offered - essentially, a rustic place - too close to a busy road, and quite gloomy / dark. Not even a bedside table with bedside reading lamp, just a hanging light bulb in the room, mattresses were old and deformed, louvered type windows letting in the mosquitoes. The aging owners were friendly, but it was obvious that they were not putting any money back into the upkeep/upgrading of their place. It has some potential, but without re-investment, or without at least a 50% price reduction to reflect the appropriate value, it cannot be recommended.After 5 days, we inspected Hob House B&B - for nearly the same price, we found ourselves in a modern and very cozy, bright and very well furnished home in a much quieter neighbourhood, with a very nice backyard terrace. The owners were very warm and engaging and helped us find our way around - even taking the family outings and to local restaurants. Highly recommended.Warmest regards,Heather BlenkironEdited: 02 February 2014, 09:58

title: How safe is Nairobi , Thika

answers.body: Generally Kenya has a mild, tropical climate, with moderate changes of temperature throughout the year. There are no winters or summers as such for the whole of East Africa. There are 2 distinct rainy seasons, one from April to early June and the other from October to November. December to February is generally warm and sunny.Thika is a good place to live and there is a big Indian community who work and live there.

answers.title: 5.Re: How safe is Nairobi , Thika

answers.body: We have lived in Thika on and off for several years and its my wife's local town. As with anywhere, there are good and bad areas. On the whole, the town centre is as safe as Nairobi. We started in Ngoingwa before it became too developed, but crime increased sharply and eventually we were broken into. Although there are some nice houses in Ngoingwa, there are also lots of one room houses and temporary structures - I wouldn't recommend living there.We moved to Bendor Estate, which is in the north of the town. This is one of the more secure estates in Thika (it has a security barrier) and is well worth considering - very little crime. There is a mix of Kenyans and Kenyan Indians living there.There is a big Indian community in Section 9. Maki, Maporomoko and (a little further from town) Bahati Ridge are all areas worth considering as good areas in which to live.Thika is an industrial town and since the highway linking it to Nairobi was completed, its become very popular with commuters looking to move away from the city. Unfortunately, the road network into Thika itself hasn't been upgraded at the same pace, so traffic into/out of the town centre is horrendous for large parts of the day (except for Sunday). Parking in the town centre is challenging. There are lots of Tuk Tuk's which can usually bypass the worst of the traffic.Thika is at slightly lower altitude than Nairobi (around 5300ft) and is noticeably warmer and drier (although the water supply is more reliable than Nairobi's).As for chocolate -Kenyaisn't a cocoa growing nation and quality chocolate is difficult to find outside Nairobi.
answers.title: 6.Re: How safe is Nairobi , Thika

answers.body: I just found the names of two chocolate shops on Facebook which get excellent reviews. One of them is Absolute Chocolate Limited which is located at the Village Market in Girgiri. The other is Velvet which is in Langata. They both produce artisanal chocolates.

Getting replacement cars took my driver the bulk of an evening that involved one call then another then another. The whole process was suspicious and shady. In America, this debacle would result in a full refund, but in this case, absolutely not. I'd never use them again because they seem to not have their own fleet of vehicles but hire them from random Kenyan private citizens that may or may not be legitimate. Beware of them!

Make sure you either wear something that you don't care about because they can splash the mud on you but fun to watch. The evening visit from 5-6pm, for those that have adopted ellies, is a different experience and very enjoyable. You get to meet the keepers and see your adopted chubby.Kazuri beads is also great. The tour of the bead making area is very interesting and the ladies very proud of their work. Their finished products are very reasonable in cost here. If you buy the same type of items at lodging, they are way more expensive.Utmanduni Crafts is also in the Karen area and is a great place to have lunch and shop. There is no pressure on the shopping like other places you might encounter. You can browse and bring your items to a central checkout. Prices are slightly higher than booths along the road, but it is wonderful to not have to haggle. They have clean bathrooms and their food is good and very reasonable.Laurena

body: Does anyone have suggestions for a reliable, well priced car-hire company in Nairobi for a short-term rental? A small 4wd (eg Suzuki Jimney) or bakkie or elevated vehicle would be ideal, but small sedan also ok.And any tips on driving, ability to find parking.Thanks
title: Car Hire (self drive) in Nairobi

answers.body: I always recommend Corcorde - I've used them many times and found their Suzukis (well, Marutis) very reliable, and they're well located in the heart of Westlands, just off Waiyaki Way.Driving tips? Where to begin?! You need to be robustly defensive, always alert, and always prepared for the worst possible outcome. It's much better to hire a driver when you hire the vehicle. Parking is a serious problem in the CBD and other busy areas. Buy parking tickets (usually valid all day) from parking wardens. And beware the city askaris, who are a law unto themselves…Happy driving!Richard Trillo
answers.title: 1.Re: Car Hire (self drive) in Nairobi

answers.body: thanks, Richard ... Corcorde or Concorde?
answers.title: 2.Re: Car Hire (self drive) in Nairobi

answers.body: Yacht,Richard I am certain meant Concorde, I have seen him mention them before. His fingers are obviously having a very bad day, it is not often he makes mistakes!GJ
answers.title: 3.Re: Car Hire (self drive) in Nairobi

answers.body: I take it you are only driving around NBO for a few days and are not considering ‘wandering’ too far.In addition to Richard’s comments, I will add. Pack an abundance of patience, and have a good look at where you are going, the routes and alternative routes before you depart, sitting with a Map of NBO will pass a few hours on the flight!The traffic can be bordering ‘evil’ at times, so give yourself plenty, and I really do mean plenty of time if you are heading somewhere for a specific time.I too would advise a driver with their own vehicle for a day, you have no worries about parking, security of the car and the routes, they know all the short cuts you would not find, etc. Their fees, so I have read, I have never used them myself, probably don’t add up to much more than car hire and fuel!If you intend to head off beyond NBO, shout again, I am sure there is much we can all add about driving outside the City.
answers.title: 4.Re: Car Hire (self drive) in Nairobi

answers.body: Thanks! Warnings headed.How bad IS the traffic? Do you have another city that you can compare it to?Bangkok, KL, Cairo and Mumbai are my reference points in order of ascending chaos!The reason we are considering car hire is primarily to enable us to do theNairobi National Parkin our own time at our own speed. We would use the car to get from airport to Karen mid-afternoon Friday, and after that maybe to go one place in the area to do some birding if time permits. Early morning to the Park (to be there when it opens) and then if we do not spend the full day in the park to go to one or more of the following:Karura Forest, Ngong Forest,Giraffe Centrenature trail, Arboretum. I am assuming the 1st 3 are easier options wrt traffic. Back to Karen and then early morning to JK airport to be there for 7am (Sunday).Your thoughts appreciated.
answers.title: 5.Re: Car Hire (self drive) in Nairobi

answers.body: Yacht,I supposeBangkokis a fair comparison.If you are only going between Jomo and Karen, with a few trips for birds and NBO Park, I cannot see you encountering any major problems. The Park is off Langata Rd, which is what you will use to get to Keran from Jomo. At the moment there are some works going on there, so it is a little more depressing than usual, but no world shattering.Also, the Park is one of those on the ‘Card system’, you could actually stop and do all the paperwork the day before going in, thus making entry quicker on the morning you visit. Sometimes there can be a queue at the desk, and anything you can do to avoid it gives you more time actually in there! Ideally, you want to hit the Gate at 0630ish.I would also opt for Ngong over Karuru forest, nothing to do with the birds, I don’t know enough, just that the latter is over by Muthaiga and you’d have to battle through town!If you come out early, and are puckish, there is a reasonable place to eat just by the Gift Shop, then you can get back on the road to theGiraffe Centre, that has a small Café too, but is really form emergency eats! You may also wish to consider the Elephant Orphange, also in the area, time dependant.For a good feed in the evening, I would head for theTalisman, excellent place about 2 mins from Karen Shops, get your hotel to book a table though, it can get a little busy and try to eat on the Patio, it makes for a nice evening.Do beware, particularly when heading into the road-works on Langata of Matatus, they don’t take prisoners and will when the traffic merges attempt to push you off the road to make space for themselves. For a first time driver over there, I would say bow out gracefully and let them in, it is better than ending up in the ditch.Be lucky and enjoy!
answers.title: 6.Re: Car Hire (self drive) in Nairobi

answers.body: Thanks for all the tips freely shared :)
answers.title: 7.Re: Car Hire (self drive) in Nairobi

answers.body: Also make sure that the car you hire allows you to go "off road" asNairobi National Parkis considered "off road". If you have an accident, then insurance won't cover it.
answers.title: 8.Re: Car Hire (self drive) in Nairobi

answers.body: Couple of thoughts:Arriving at JKIA mid-afternoon Friday and trying to drive to Karen, you will probably (depending on flight arrival time) get as far as Uhuru Stadium roundabout before encountering traffic heading left (west) to Karen that will take you 1-2 hours, so don't expect to be in Karen much before dark (6.30pm).I'd suggest you might do better to get a taxis on Friday and Sunday and have a car and driver for the whole of Saturday, someone who will pick you up from where you're staying and drop you back at the end of the day. There's not much point in renting for such a short time, IMHO. Not to be a downer on the plan. And there are no standard car-rental outlets at the airport.Richard Trillo

title: Stuff to do in Nairobi

answers.body: We had a request like that some time back and ended up doing the below itinerary which catered for our day. The trip was made possible by diwaka safaris based in Nairobi and we were provided with an extra free guide..if need be,just write to joseph@diwakasafaris.com11thPicked at 1000hrs for a 20 mins drive to the Daphne Sheldrik Elephant orphanage for a one hour learning experience about the playful young elephants and rhino that were rescued. (1100-1200hrs).The David Sheldrick Wildlife Trustis a small flexible charity, established in memory of David Sheldrick, famous Naturalist and founder Warden of Kenya's giant Tsavo East National Park in which he served from 1948 until 1976.The trust has been active in an educative capacity and provided a blue print for the welfare of animals in captivity and in cases of elephants, illustrated the sophistication of their communication and their social needs.1230hrs: Taken to a restaurant where you pay for your lunch directly1400hrs: Proceed short drive to the nearbyGiraffe Centre.It’s a sanctuary for the rare and beautiful Rothschild Giraffe set by Jock a British-born Kenyan citizen with the help of her American Wife Betty Leslie-Melville. Not only will you get to have a close view of the tall mammals but also be able to have a rare chance to hold a wild animal as you feed them ending with a most wonderful kiss from them. The residents’ warthogs are also a good sight to catch with their “same as” pig behavior.1500hrs: End the day with a visit to theKaren Blixen Museumplus shopping before been dropped back at the Hilton Hotel.A visit to the original home of the famous Danish Authoress of (Out of Africa Movie fame) giving you an incredible chance to learn more about the widely respected woman as you take a graceful walk around the around her spacious bungalow. You can take a walk around the beautiful gardens with spectacular view of the knuckles likeNgong Hillswhere Blixen boyfriend Denys Finch Hatton was remains were laid to rest on May 14 1931.

answers.title: 2.Re: Best use of One Day at Giraffe Manor?

answers.body: Hello,I work withGiraffe Manoras their sales and marketing representative in Europe and hope I can help here. The giraffe visit the Manor in the morning until around 8am. It is difficult to say exactly where they will be and when as they have the whole garden to explore throughout the day, but it is safe to say that you will see them before 8am up at the Manor and also around tea time when they like to come up again! I have arrived at the manor at various times of the day and there is almost always a giraffe in sight , be it by the Manor or just down the hill.Re: what to do, you can walk to the giraffe centre from the Manor so, as you say this is a must. I would suggest going to the private session only at the Daphne Sheldrick orphanage. This is far more personalised and you will be able to ask specific questions about your elephant as well as seeing some of the others. The afternoon session can have as many as 150 people there and, although interesting for those who are not able to have a private viewing, is not as special. I would suggest that, as your time is short that you only do the private session.Depending on what you are most interested in, whilst you are coming back from the Daphne Sheldrick orphanage I would highly recommend stopping in at Marula studios. This is where they recycle flipflops from the Kenyan coast (they are washed up onto the beach and turtles have been killed by trying to eat them so they are removed and brought to Nairobi). Here they are made into all sorts of wonderful things such as toys, jewellery, mats etc. You can look around the factory and then head into the shop to see the end products. Kazuri beads is great for souvenir shopping and Matt Bronze is great to visit / see the bronzes being made and buy something of quality. Karen Blixen is also nice to see if you are interested in her history, but again, depending on your time you may want to get back to the Manor. You really do not want to miss out on the tea on the lawn with giraffe! Once you are back at the Manor you can enjoy the rest of the day / evening there. What is great is that the Manor is close to all these places, so it really comes down to your own preference. Hope this helps and you have a wonderful time there!

answers.body: Here's my 2 shillings worth:Giraffe Manoris a unique place to stay. It's 28km from Nairobi International Airport and assuming you're out of the airport and moving in a vehicle by 7.30am (pretty good going if you are), you won't be at Giraffe Manor until 9 or 9.30am, except possibly on a Sunday. BUT, you won't be able to check-in until 10.45/11am for the reasons Sandi states - there's no waiting area, no lobby and they're checking guests *out* between 10 and 11. So, you'll be hanging around for a bit, possibly at the AFEW Giraffe Centre itself (to which as guests of GM you would have free access, though possibly only once you've checked in…), which is just across the lawn, on the edge of the manor grounds.The bigger question is: if you aren't already holding a room at Giraffe Manor, book one soon. It's often full.As for the question of how to fill the 24 hours: "Karen Blixen museum, bomas, Matt Bronze, Kazuki beads, open air market - which one?" Kazuri Beads is nice, but I wouldn't pass up the opportunity to visitNairobi National Parkproperly - it's a really impressive 60 square miles of wilderness, not some sanitised city park, and you have a very good chance of seeing lions, and even greater chance (amazingly) of seeing both black and white rhinos.Have a great stay in Nairobi - a greatly underrated city.Richard Trillo
