body: I got roped into a holiday with the family toKenyaand am a bit nervous as my 2.5 year old toddler with be accompanying us too! Any comments on how child-friendly a place Nairobi is? My main queries surround entertainment (parks/playgrounds), health and safety (food/water) and infrastructure (cleanliness, public toilets, change-facilities, etc). Its too late to change plans now, so the best I can do is make sure that my kid is healthy, relatively well entertained and happy! We're going on a couple of private safaris where kids are allowed, though I wonder if he'll really enjoy them. Any warnings, pointers, hints, suggestions, advice is welcome!
title: Nairobi and Kenya for toddlers

answers.body: I'm not sure I would have taken such a young child. I think 5 is possibly the earliest I would take a little one. At the very least they need to be able to take malaria prophylactics and I don't think I could have got the tablets into my kids at that age.Having said that just make sure that he/she has all the recommended jabs; use bottled water; take care with the sun - all the things that apply to anyone really - and you should be OK.There are things for little ones in Nairobi - the elephant orphanage and giraffe centre are perfect. There is also Uhuru park which has pedallos, rides etc. Most hotels have swimming pools too so you should be able to fill the time that you are there and most Kenyans do like children - well at least that's been my experience.
answers.title: 1.Re: Nairobi and Kenya for toddlers

answers.body: We took our two young ones last year ages 4 and 8 (younger one turned 5 while in the Mara - "best birthday present ever") We had private driver so that we could change plans, stop whenever needed, etc. Children will love it, but maybe not remember it as much as an older child would.We were able to get medicine in them by crushing and mixing with chocolate pudding so it can be done. Bottle water all the way, hats, sunscreen and short days and you will be fine. If you have not already, be sure to visit travel clinic and get antibiotic prescriptions filled ahead for all travellers and take with you for emergency. We were there for 35 days and used ours.Don't expect to be taking a stroller as it will be useless on the poor roads, sidewalks except maybe in downtown Nairobi. Back pack carrier for that age might be useful. But taxis and guide will get you wherever you need to go so you should not have to carry that much.And to compare, we also went to India for 60 days when youngest was at the around same age as yours.Kenyais much cleaner and safer than crowed India.
answers.title: 2.Re: Nairobi and Kenya for toddlers

answers.body: Be sure to prearrange for a bed (even a crib) with a bed net for the little one. Not all camps/lodges have these as they're not always necessary, but I sure would for a little one. And for certain be sure to give him/her their malaria meds daily. There are a few types, but Malarone does have a pediatric dosage for child under 40lbs. Discuss with doc meds and inocs that all might need as even most adults haven't been since childhood - Tetanus, HepA, Polio.Besides forgetting about a stroller, know that most safari vehicles have seat belts but NOT childseats, so you might want to seriously consider one as the roads in some areas aren't the best. The little one will also often need a nap midday, so having one is best.Also be aware that you can arrange for an anya ( nanny, reasonably priced ) if you wish your own time, as a quiet dinner. Remember though that those younger than 4/yrs rarely remember the experience... sure from photos within a year or two after the trip, but by 6-7/yrs, it'll be long forgotten.As you'll have own guide/driver you'll be able to set your own schedule. While there are pools, whether at NBO hotels or when out on safari, few if any are heated, so keep that in mind.
answers.title: 3.Re: Nairobi and Kenya for toddlers

answers.body: Thanks everyone, that's really helpful. I just want to make sure our son stays healthy and relatively well entertained. I wonder how much tolerance he'll have for safaris, if not interspersed with the things he's used to like parks, playgrounds, other kids, cafes and all that jazz. I'm pretty sure he'd get more excited patting a cow in a paddock than seeing a lion out in the distance!Rod T, quick question- what kinds of illnesses did your kids face that you needed the antibiotics for? Hats off for the 60 days in India with a toddler! We live in India at the moment, so he's used to the bugs here, but I don't think I'd have the guts to visit with him if he hadn't already spent most of his life here!
answers.title: 4.Re: Nairobi and Kenya for toddlers

answers.body: Just the usual vomiting and diarrhea. No hospital visits. We all had it at the same time during one night while on safari and staying in a small cabin so likely spoiled food from a roadside stop on the way there. That was a night to remember for sure with only one bathroom between four of us. Several doses of strong antibiotics, water with electrolytes and soda water and 24 hours later all was fine and forgotten.We loved India as my wife has family there. Travelled the southern third and then the golden triangle. India is great for travel with hiring drivers and cars for ten days at a time and with kids it was much cheaper than private safari in Africa. And with the lions and other animals, they will not be off in the distance, they will be right beside the vehicle.

title: 3 Days in Nairobi before Safari - what to do

answers.body: We went on a safari last year. Before the safari we enjoyed 2 days in Nairobi. We hired a driver who picked us up from our hotel (The Sarova Stanley). We went to the Elephant orphanage, Kazuri Bead factory (hand made bead--made by local widows from the area--go and support them if you can--nice jewlery that you can only get in Nairobi) and to the Giraffe Center. We also asked our driver to take us to a shopping center so we could buy some snacks and drinks. He also took us by the slums of Nairobi (Kibera). I wish we would have spent more time in the slums. The people there were so friendly and the living conditions were so much different than what we see in America.We also changed money at a bank at the "mall." This bank had a much better exchange rate than we got at the hotel. Also, it is better to haveKenyashillings for the Elephant orphanage and the Giraffe center. No credit cards accepted and the rate for US money (which they do accept) is far, far worse than if you use their currency.we went to Karen Blixen's Coffee House for lunch too--such a nice place to eat!!! You will love it!Hope this helps!!

body: I am flying into Nairobi on a Saturday evening in August (flight is scheduled to arrive at 6:10pm) in advance of a Kilimanjaro trek the following week - starting from Moshi.Any suggestions on transport?I did look in my Tanzania Lonely Planet book, but am having a lot of trouble sorting through the various options:I think there might be at least one overnight (Scandinavian?) bus leaving late Saturday night. On the other hand, I am considering spending that Saturday night in a Nairobi hotel and then catching a bus on Sunday.Any thoughts/suggestions/recommendations would be greatly appreciated... both about the bus or perhaps about a convenient hotel to stay at for the night in Nairobi if I choose to do that.Thanks!Sam
title: Nairobi to Moshi transport questions

answers.body: I highly discourage overnight buses in East Africa period. It's the height of banditry and when most fatal accidents occur (though this is rare on that route). If you have never been in Africa before (especiallyKenya), it would be nice for you to travel during the day so you have your bearings. People unfamiliar with their surroundings (it seems) are more commonly victims of crime/petty theft. Not to scare you, but I've heard so many stories (and never been a crime victim myself because I'm overly-cautious) so I think you should heed my advise. You would be best-served to take a bus or shuttle the next morning and grab a hotel on Sunday. You will route through Arusha and then onward to Moshi. The Impala shuttle is comfortablehttp://www.impalashuttle.com/and will get you to Moshi. Riverside shuttle is another option, but there have been a few bad reviews on this forum latelyhttp://www.riverside-shuttle.com/.I can't speak for Scandinavian, as the quality of buses change from year to year or month to month. It used to look decent (haven't ever taken them myself) but that can change quickly. I like the shuttles, and they are pretty comfortable compared to the buses. Again a bus in Kenya cannot be compared to a bus in the US.Good luck.
answers.title: 1.Re: Nairobi to Moshi transport questions

answers.body: Best to spend first night in Nairobi, get a good night's rest before considering going onward. Especially not a good idea to do this in the dark.Spend the night in Nairobi and if time allows for when you begin your trek from Moshi, do some sightseeing in/around and maybe head out the followiing day - Monday.However many days in NBO, please no nighttime bus rides. Whether Impala, Riverside or Scandinavia, best to ride during daylight hours.

body: My best friend & I are thinking about spending 2 days in Nairobi after working with an NGO in Arusha for two weeks in June. How close is downtown Nairobi to the airport? Also, are there many worthwhile sights to see in just two days? Any suggestions? Is it safe for two women travelling together?
title: Itinerary suggestions for two days in Nairobi?

answers.body: Jomo Kenyatta airport to downtown Nairobi takes approx 30 minutes depending on traffic. Wilson airport is a little closer. Precision Air flies between Kilimanjaro and Jomo Kenyatta. Air Kenya and Safarilink fly between Arusha/Kilimanjaro and Wilson. There's also a shuttle which runs twice daily between Arusha and Nairobi and takes about 5 hours (you'll go through immigration at the Namanga border in between).Here's a previous thread which listed a few things to do in Nairobi -tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294207-i9695-k478…Take sensible precautions during the day and do not walk around at night. It's generally safe to walk around the downtown area in the daytime, but check with the hotel staff and see what they advise. Leave any valuables in the hotel safe and carry only what you need for the day. Stick with taxis at night and have the taxi wait for you and bring you back to the hotel.Hope this helps.

answers.body: Hi Longhorn, it is an exciting place Nairobi is...you can travel from Arusha to Nairobi using shuttles that operate daily...there are a number of them. Also, there are a number of areas you can visit in Nairobi that could interest you very much:- The Nairobi national park, where you can see all of the big five animals except the elephant.- Giraffe manor and Karen blixen museum-Snake Park, where several rare snake species are on display, and the Nairobi museum- The famous University of Nairobi- Bomas ofKenyafor traditional cultural shows- Carnivore restaurant for delicious exotic meals- As patty said, you can visit Lake Naivasha or Lake Nakuru. You can also visit further places other than there e.g. the bubbling hot springs of Lake Bogoria or Amboseli tour or thompson falls in aberdaresThere are tons of other places you can visit. Yeah its pretty safe during the day. At night is not very safe in some areas However it is usually better to have a designated guide who can ensure you dont waste time wound up looking for places around the town. Even with your guide, you can travel safely at night. These guys can help you they are at a site called ealuxuryshuttle.com for advice and more trips and packages. Sorry for many stories but East Africa is a lovely place...theres much to write home about...Cheers, hope you enjoy your stay.

answers.title: 5.Re: Itinerary suggestions for two days in Nairobi?

answers.body: My family and I have been in Nairobi for a month. We have really enjoyed theGiraffe Centrewhere you can hand feed giraffes. Nearby is a place called Sheldricks Elephant Orphanage. It is only open from 11-12 and they bring out baby elephants that they are caring for. At theNairobi National Parkyou can do a few things. Firstly, you can go by car and drive around the park looking at all the animals. This was our first "safari" experience and we thought it was great. We were there all day, though. You get a 24 hour pass so you could come and go I think. Also at the park is the safari walk which is fun and also the animal orphange which is interesting as well. You have to pay for each place. It's $40US for the park and I think $10 each for the other two.All of these places are on the way to Karen where theKaren Blixen Museumis. I haven't been there yet, but plan to go. The area is very green and picturesque. We haven't been to Carnivore's yet but there is a neat bar called Casablancas in the Kilimani area. It has an outdoor area with open fires and chairs around them. Well worth a visit.Anyway, hope this helps and you have fun.

Last stop can be Sheldrick Orphanage for foster parents.At Kazuri there are items at all prices, few very inexpensive and $20 might be cutting it close. What I like as gifts and reasonaly priced - the wire necklace or bracelet with beads along wire with matching earrings. title: Langata / Karen area

answers.body: I live in Nairobi for ten months of the year, and can assure you that yes you can walk around during the day, especially in some areas. I can assure you that Karen is a safe area to walk alone in the daytime. I never walk alone in Nairobi at night.Furthermore, it's in Nairobi's numerous slum areas that rates of crime are so high. Black people are far more likely to be the victims of crime than whites.

body: Dear PalsI will have 8 hours to visit Nairobi before safari, my plan is as below:07:00 Breakfast09:00 Giraffe Center11:00 Sheldrick Elephant Orphanage12:30 Carnivore orHaandiAfter lunch, I don't know which place is most recommendable to stay, such as (1)Karen Blixen Museum(2)National Museumor any other place?Hope somebody could review my schedule and recommend a nice place to stay in the afternoon!Any suggestions are appreciated!
title: 8 hours in Nairobi, please help for the schedule

answers.body: Depends on what your interests are. If you're an Out of Africa fan, you can't miss the Blixen Museum. If you're not an Out of Africa fan, you might not find it so interesting. The museum is very close to theGiraffe Centreand Sheldrick. Don't know if you're interested in any shopping stops but also nearby are Kazuri Beads & Pottery and Utamaduni which has a craft collection (prices a bit high but good quality and selection). If you decide to go to the Blixen Museum in the afternoon, I'd stick with the Carnivore for lunch asHaandiis in Westlands and you don't want to have to drive back and forth across the city. Or pick some place in the Karen/Langata area to have lunch.The Verandahrestaurant at Utamaduni is a nice spot. But of course, not the same atmosphere as Carnivore.I haven't been to theNational Museum. Tried to visit several times but it was always under renovation. Lunch at Haandi would be fine if that's your afternoon plan.Another museum is theRailway Museumby the train station. It houses old engines, rail cars and memorabilia from the East African Railway if that's something that might interest you.Enjoy your trip!

body: My wife will be celebrating a special birthday while we are in Nairobi, so I'm booking a night atGiraffe Manor(she'd hate the price if she knew, but she does adore those giraffes...). We've been asked which room we'd like (subject to availability, obviously). I'm assuming that we'd prefer to be on the first-floor (UK-speak) i.e. second-floor (US-speak) and to be overlooking the front 'garden' - but I've only been able to find the names of the 6 rooms, not their locations or their relative merits. If anyone has any opinions as to which rooms work best (or worst....) I'd be very grateful.I've also seen a suggestion that - because of the extra food on offer during most of the day at the adjacentGiraffe Centre- giraffes only tend to gather at Giraffe Manor around breakfast-time and in late afternoon. Is that so, or can we expect some giraffe encounters at Giraffe Manor on and off for most of the day (we'll be checking in around 11 am)?
title: Giraffe Manor: question for anyone who has stayed there

answers.body: If you wish a front/garden facing room,, then be specific. But the two that are (best I know) may only have two-beds, not a queen/king... why you should inquire on details.As the photos on their site, the room (center column down #6, where I stayed) is front/side facing, but as you'll note is 2/full-size beds, but also a fireplace. Bathroom is adjacent with tub-shower/washbasin, next to that is room with the commode/loo. Behind that is another bedroom with queen (or maybe king) sized bed. So both sleeping rooms share the same bathroom/loo. Don't know the names of either of these rooms, but would be good for a family to share.Believe it's the same on other side of the Mansion with similar setup. And, then a few rooms to the rear of the building.Regarding the girafes, they do show up for breakfast and late afternoon - for cocktails :). During mid-day they're usually over at the Center where they're fed by visitors. But the Tall Blondes do wander from place-to-place on the property.Sorry I don't have further room details. Best to write directly with your questions.
answers.title: 1.Re: Giraffe Manor: question for anyone who has stayed there

answers.body: Many thanks, 4sandi. Point taken about enquiring directly - butGiraffe Manorisn't incredibly forthcoming in their e-mails, which is why any first-hand feedback from people who have actually stayed there is so much appreciated.
answers.title: 2.Re: Giraffe Manor: question for anyone who has stayed there

answers.body: If working thru a tour operator/agent/outfitter, they should be able toget specific answers from the Manor. Otherwise, if booking directly, keep writing but stay pleasant even if you're getting annoyed.
answers.title: 3.Re: Giraffe Manor: question for anyone who has stayed there

answers.body: We stayed there for 2 nights in Oct 2008 and it was the highlight of my holiday...if you look at the picture of the Manor on their homepage we stayed in the room on the top floor on the left, it had a black marble bathroom if that helps - it was lovely! I think it was also the 1st picture on the accommodation page - we had Giraffe with their heads through our window!! I would mention that as it is art-dec bathroom there was not shower head for me to wash my hair so I did use a shower next door to our room instead.Our friends had the bedroom the other side and their bathroom was not on-suite but just across the hall but the angle of the hall meant no one could see them making the step across. And their bedroom was also lovelyAs far as I remember I would have been happy to stay in any of the rooms but think I was in the best.As for Giraffe they mainly stopped by at breakfast and tea but on one day we did have them visit at lunchtime - we did make use of the car and driver though and go to the elephant orphanage which is just down the road so we were not there all the time.....we also visited the Giraffe centre and went for a walk in their small nature reserve across the road, which is also included in the cost of a night stay, so you can see as much of the giraffes as you want.Please let me know if you have any more questions......is it worth the cost...well the 4 of us thought so!!
answers.title: 4.Re: Giraffe Manor: question for anyone who has stayed there

answers.body: Very helpful – thank you. I now see fromGiraffe Manor’s Facebook page that they have renovated/upgraded several rooms (all are now en-suite); the Facebook page has photos of some of the revamped rooms. They also seem to have changed the names of all the rooms quite recently, just to add to my confusion. What is now Jock’s Room (ex-Morning Room) has a fireplace, and front/side windows, and doesn’t seem to interlink with any other room, so maybe we'll try for that. I know we’ll be happy wherever we end up – I’m just trying to make it the most special-occasion I can!One other question…. We are adopting a baby ellie so will want to visit the Sheldrick centre for the 5pm to 6pm ‘bedtime’ while we are in Nairobi. We could do that the day after we leave Giraffe Manor, but logistically it would be more convenient to do it during our one day/night at GM. However, that would no doubt mean that we were away from GM from 4.40pm to 6.20pm or so. If that is a peak giraffe-cocktail time at GM, then presumably we’d be silly to go off-site then? Or would there be plenty of time to enjoy the giraffes (and the cocktails) between getting back around 6.20pm and whenever dinner takes place?
answers.title: 5.Re: Giraffe Manor: question for anyone who has stayed there

answers.body: We were inKenyain late August and also adopted an elephant. We went to the elephant center for the 11am "viewing", they are quite strict and this lasts from 11am sharp to noon. We then came back at 5pm and were probably there for about 90 minutes. It would seem to me that based upon the price at the Manor it may not be worthwhile to spend one night if you are going to be away so much during the day.We visited the visitors center and spent about 2 hours there. There are a few tables and chairs under umbrellas and of course the giraffes to feed. IT was a wonderful experience and although we tried to get rooms at the Manor (they were booked) it worked out well that we did not stay there. After a couple of hours with the giraffes there is really not much else to do.

body: I am flying through Nairobi on my way toRwanda, and due to connections, have to do an overnight in Nairobi. Can anyone recommend a good hotel for an overnight that would have transportation from the airport? I assume there are no hotels actually at the airport. I don't have any daylight time to be exploring the city, and depart early in the morning, so I am just looking for a close place to sleep.Thanks for any suggestions,Fawn
title: overnight in Nairobi

answers.body: There's Panari Hotel & Ole Sereni Hotel. Both in close proximity to airport.Go forOle Serenib'coz it's fairly new & it overlooksNairobiNational Parkhttp://www.ole-serenihotel.com/location.htmStef

answers.body: HeyThanks for that! I also have to overnight in Nairobi enroute toRwanda, and need somewhere to shower, eat and sleep!!happy travels** Ohh I just checked out prices USD$350 - way out of my budget for one night!Anyone know of a cheap hotel close to airport??Edited: 05 May 2010, 13:57

answers.body: FawnIf you get in late, and are leaving early, you should be able to use the Sleep and Shower facility inside the airport itself. It's fairly basic but secure. $40 for up to 8 hours.Good luck.Richard

answers.body: jambo fawn_7if youa re getting in late (after 9.00 pm) and leaving hotel before 6.00 am then traffic should not be too horrendous for you to get into the city..so you can try the country lodge - its safe and clean and not more than $100 and you can get a meal next door from the fairview...its a small lodge so try your luck with reservations..

answers.body: Have a look at posts on Sleep 'n' Shower. It is down the stairs (or use the lift) just past Gate 4.No visa fees, no taxi. Eating places on arrivals/departure level - or bring your spares from the plane!! If your luggage is checked through, you won't need to worry about that.
